user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, OS_SocketDomain_t Domain)
{
    sa_family_t             sa_family;
    socklen_t               addrlen;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    memset(Addr, 0, sizeof(OS_SockAddr_t));
    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Domain)
    {
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET:
            sa_family = AF_INET;
            addrlen   = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET6:
            sa_family = AF_INET6;
            addrlen   = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            sa_family = 0;
            addrlen   = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    Addr->ActualLength     = OSAL_SIZE_C(addrlen);
    Accessor->sa.sa_family = sa_family;

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl:
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketDomain_INVALID, /**< @brief Invalid */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET,    /**< @brief IPv4 address family, most commonly used) */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET6,   /**< @brief IPv6 address family, depends on OS/network stack support */
    OS_SocketDomain_MAX      /**< @brief Maximum */
} OS_SocketDomain_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OSAL_SIZE_C(X) ((size_t)(X))
...
#define OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED (-28)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_SocketAddrInit(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, OS_SocketDomain_t Domain)
{
    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Addr);

    return OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl(Addr, Domain);
}
...
int32 OS_SocketAccept(osal_id_t sock_id, osal_id_t *connsock_id, OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_common_record_t *         sock_record;
    OS_common_record_t *         conn_record;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *sock;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *conn;
    OS_object_token_t            sock_token;
    OS_object_token_t            conn_token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Addr);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(connsock_id);

    /*
     * Note: setting "connrecord" here avoids a false warning
     * from static analysis tools about the value being
     * possibly used uninitialized (it cannot be, because
     * return_code is checked, and return_code is only
     * set to OS_SUCCESS when connrecord is also initialized)
     */
    conn_record = NULL;
    sock_record = NULL;
    sock        = NULL;
    conn        = NULL;
    memset(&sock_token, 0, sizeof(sock_token));
    memset(&conn_token, 0, sizeof(conn_token));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &sock_token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        sock_record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, sock_token);
        sock        = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, sock_token);

        if (sock->socket_type != OS_SocketType_STREAM)
        {
            /* Socket must be of the STREAM variety */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((sock->stream_state & (OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND | OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED)) != OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND)
        {
            /* Socket must be bound but not connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            /* Now create a unique ID for the connection */
            return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, NULL, &conn_token);
            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                conn_record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, conn_token);
                conn        = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, conn_token);

                /* Incr the refcount to record the fact that an operation is pending on this */
                memset(conn, 0, sizeof(OS_stream_internal_record_t));

                conn->socket_domain = sock->socket_domain;
                conn->socket_type   = sock->socket_type;

                OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl(Addr, sock->socket_domain);

                return_code = OS_SocketAccept_Impl(&sock_token, &conn_token, Addr, timeout);

                if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
                {
                    /* Generate an entry name based on the remote address */
                    OS_CreateSocketName(&conn_token, Addr, sock_record->name_entry);
                    conn_record->name_entry = conn->stream_name;
                    conn->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED;
                }

                return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &conn_token, connsock_id);
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&sock_token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketDomain_INVALID, /**< @brief Invalid */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET,    /**< @brief IPv4 address family, most commonly used) */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET6,   /**< @brief IPv6 address family, depends on OS/network stack support */
    OS_SocketDomain_MAX      /**< @brief Maximum */
} OS_SocketDomain_t
explanation:
The items listed above are the code locations that could lead to unreachable-code concerns and therefore merit investigation for compliance with MISRA C Rule 2.1: the switch handling of domain values (including the conditional IPv6 case and the default branch), the subsequent early return when addrlen == 0, and the code that follows that return which is executed only when addrlen != 0. Also included are the enum definition and the OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 macro because the presence/absence of the macro and the enum values affect which switch branches are possible and thus whether any branch is unreachable.

Why other fragments need not be investigated for unreachable-code at this time:
- The local variable declarations and the initial memset/Accessor assignment are reachable and used by both possible function outcomes (return early or proceed to success), so they do not constitute unreachable code.
- The OS_SocketAccept function’s control flow (initializations, checks, token handling, and calls) contains no statements that are syntactically impossible to reach: conditional blocks are guarded by runtime return_code checks, and variables explicitly initialized to avoid use-before-set warnings are then assigned inside those conditionals. There are no obvious statements after unconditional returns or infinite loops that would make code unreachable in the provided fragments.
- Preprocessor guards are included among the suspicious fragments above; other uses of the union and assignments (e.g., Accessor->sa.sa_family) are conditional on runtime values and therefore are not intrinsically unreachable.

Investigate the listed fragments to confirm that each case of the Domain enum is intended to be reachable (or intentionally guarded) and that compilation-time switches (OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6) do not leave portions of the switch or enum unreachable in the project configuration(s).
